frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A solid uniform disk is supported by a vertical stand. The disk is able to rotate with negligible friction about an axle that passes through the center of the disk. The mass and radius of the disk are given by <math alttext="M sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, respectively. The rotational inertia of the disk is <math alttext="I sub d equals, one half M sub d, end sub, times R squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. A string of negligible mass is draped over the disk and attached to the top of the disk at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math>. One end of the string is connected to an unstretched ideal spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, which is fixed to the ground as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A block of mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> is then attached to the string on the right side of the disk. The block is slowly lowered until the spring-disk-block system reaches equilibrium, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. In this equilibrium position, the disk has rotated clockwise through a small angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>. Give all algebraic answers in terms of <math alttext="M sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>M</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. (a) Derive an expression for the mass <math alttext="m sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> of the block.

(b) At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the string on the right side of the disk is cut and the block falls to the ground. On the circle below, which represents the disk, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the disk immediately after the string is cut and the block is falling to the ground. Each force should be represented by an arrow that starts on and is directed away from the point of application.
(c) Derive an expression for the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi></math> of the disk immediately after the string is cut.

(d) At <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the disk has rotated and point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>P</mtext></math> is again directly above the axle. Sketch a graph of the magnitude of the angular velocity <math alttext="omega" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ω</mi></math> of the disk as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

(e) The disk is adjusted on the support so that the axle does not pass through the center of mass (cm) of the disk. The block is again hung on the right side of the disk and the spring-disk-block system comes to equilibrium, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The axle does not exert a torque on the disk. For each force on the disk, indicate whether the magnitude of the torque about the axle caused by that force increases, decreases, or stays the same relative to part (b).
